metadata.title: Effects of physical properties of nano-sized hydroxyapatite crystals on cellular toxicity in renal epithelial cells

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Science & Engineering C
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/msec
Effects of physical properties of nano-sized hydroxyapatite crystals on cellular toxicity in renal epithelial cells
Chen-Ying Rao1, Xin-Yuan Sun1, Jian-Ming Ouyang⁎
Institute of Biomineralization and Lithiasis Research, Jinan University, Guangzhou 510632, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Hydroxyapatite Crystal morphology Cytotoxicity Kidney stones
A B S T R A C T
Hydroxyapatite (HAP) is not only a common component of most idiopathic CaOx stones, but also the core of Randall's plaque. HAP is a nest that can induce the formation of Randall's plaques and even kidney stones. We studied the toxic effects and mechanisms of four different types of nano-HAP crystals (H-Sphere, 72.5 nm×72.5 nm; H-Needle, 37.2 nm×162.7 nm; H-Rod, 42.3 nm×115.3 nm; and H-Plate, 145.5 nm×272.9 nm) on human renal proximal tubular epithelial cells (HK-2). HAP crystals could cause oxidative stress that triggered a series of cell dysfunction problems, resulting in decreased cell viability, loss of cell membrane integrity, cell swelling, and cell necrosis. The toxic effect of HAP was mainly attributed to its entry into cell by endocytosis and its accumulation in the lysosomes, causing the level of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) to rise, the mitochondrial membrane potential (Δψm) to decrease, the lysosomal integrity to be destroyed, and the cell cycle blocked during the G0/G1 phase. The cytotoxicity of the four kinds of HAP crystals was ranked as follows: H-Sphere > H-Needle > H-Rod > H-Plate. The cytotoxicity of each crystal was positively correlated with low absolute zeta potential, conduciveness to internalized morphology, large specific surface area and aspect ratio, and small particle size. These results indicated that nano-HAP could damage HK-2 cells, and the physical properties of HAP crystals play a vital effect in their cytotoxicity.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Hydroxyapatite (HAP) is the most important inorganic mineral component in bones and teeth. Research has shown that HAP at 20–40 nm plays an important role in the formation of biominerals [1]. However, not all HAP crystals are beneficial to the human body. Randall plaque formed by HAP on the surface of renal epithelial cells in the urinary system is important causes of stone formation [2]. In Randall plaques, there are HAP crystals with different sizes from nanometer to micrometer, and also HAP crystals with different morphologies [2]. Calcium oxalate (CaOx) is a common type of kidney stone whose formation mechanism is not yet fully elucidated [3]. HAP and uric acid are the main crystal nests that induce the formation of CaOx stones, but relatively few studies in this area were conducted [4,5].
Overgrowth of CaOx upon renal papillary Randall's plaque has been proposed as a potential mechanism of stone formation [6]. The percent of plaque coverage directly correlates with the number of stones formed and supports the hypothesis that the pathogenesis of CaOx stones begins with Randall's plaques [7], which are in contact with supersaturated urine in adjacent nephrons. Consequently, CaOx was induced
to precipitate on its surface and cause heterogeneous nucleation that further promotes the growth and aggregation of CaOx crystals in renal epithelial cells [8], thus increasing the risk of kidney stone formation.
HAP is the main component of Randall's plaque [2,9,10]. Evan et al.'s studies [9,10] on kidney biopsies suggested that apatite deposits at the origin of Randall's plaque originated from the basement membranes of the thin loops of Henle and subsequently spread into the vasa recta, surrounding interstitium of the ducts of Bellini, and finally to the urethral epithelium at the tip of the nipple, causing CaOx to precipitate on its surface and subsequent heterogeneous nucleation. HAP crystal deposition was also found within the collecting duct lumina.
Many calcium phosphate crystal phases were found in calcium stones or urine, and HAP were the most common calcium phosphate salts, there was substantial hydroxyapatite in most kidney stones [11]. Therefore, a close relationship exists between HAP and kidney stones. Yu et al. [12] developed an in vitro system by co-culturing HK-2 cells with different concentrations of HAP and/or macrophage cells to simulate the internal environment of urolithiasis. They found that HAP can cause oxidative stress in HK-2 cells and subsequently induced cell death. HAP increased the expression level of osteopontin in HK-2 cells,

T
and caused heterogeneous nucleation and adhesion and deposition of crystals, thereby promoting the formation of Randall's plaques and kidney stones. Escobar et al. [13] found that oxidative stress and lipid peroxidation was induced in the rat kidney cells (NRK52E) upon contact with the HAP particles. HAP caused an upregulation of inflammatory mediators, which might be responsible for kidney inflammation in patients with stone disease associated with HAP deposition in the tube. Khan et al. [14] co-cultured oxalic acid, CaOx, and HAP with canine kidney cells (MDCK), and showed that they all caused an increase in the expression of matrix gla protein (MGP) in MDCK cells, superoxide dismutase release, lactate dehydrogenase release, and increased cell death rate, thus promoting the formation of kidney stones.
Controlling physical properties of crystals plays a crucial role in elucidating the pathogenesis of diseases caused by exogenous and endogenous particles, such as kidney stones, gallstones, and atherosclerosis. The size and morphology of HAP have a significant effect on cytotoxicity [15–18]. For example, Liu et al. [16] evaluated the role of shape and size of gold nanoparticles (GNPs) in their toxicities to fungi, spherical and star/flower-shaped GNPs ranging in size from 0.7 nm to large aggregates of 400 nm were synthesized, the results showed that larger and non-spherical GNPs had relatively stronger toxicities. Pak et al. [17] revealed that the cytotoxicity of native silver materials is affected by their size and morphology. The overall toxicity was in the following order: submicro-particles>wires>micro-particles, which showed that silver wires are the most toxic among the three tested materials. Study conducted by Ispas et al. [15] on zebrafish embryos found that the toxicity of 30, 60 and 100 nm spherical nickel nanoparticles is< 60 nm dendritic clusters. This study suggests that the configuration of nanoparticles affects their toxicity more than size. Xu et al. [18] compared the effects of four different HAP morphologies (short rods, long rods, sphere, and needles) on the growth inhibition and apoptosis of primary rat osteoblasts. They found that crystals with high specific surface area had a high surface activity and was likely to attach to cells and cause toxicity.
However, the differences in the toxicity of nano-HAP crystals with different morphologies and sizes to renal epithelial cells and their effects on the formation of CaOx kidney stones remain unclear. The toxicity differences of different morphological particles may be affected by cell adhesion, endocytosis rate, and cell surface dynamics [19,20]. Based on these factors, this study compared the cytotoxicity of four different morphological nano-HAP crystals on HK-2 cells to further elucidate the pathogenesis of urinary calculi.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
2.1. Materials
sections.text: The following materials were used: human renal proximal tubular epithelial cells (HK-2; Shanghai Cell Bank, Chinese Academy of Sciences); nanosized HAP (purity≥ 97%; Huizhou Weijing Nano New Material Co., Ltd.); Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM/F-12), fetal bovine serum (FBS) and pancreatin (Gibco, Gibco, USA); penicillin and streptomycin (Beijing Pubo Biotechnology Co., Ltd., Beijing, China); cell proliferation assay kit (cell counting kit-8, CCK-8), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) kit, Hematoxylin-eosin (HE) dye, 4% paraformaldehyde, 2′,7′-dichloro-fluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) (Shanghai Beyotime Bio-Tech Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China); mitochondrial membrane potential detection kit (JC-1), Lyso-Tracker Red, acridine orange (AO) dye (Nanjing Jiancheng Technology Co., Ltd., Nanjing, China); annexin V-FITC/PI cell apoptosis and necrosis double dye kits (Beijing 4A Biotech Co., Ltd.). Other conventional chemical reagents are of analytical grade.

sections.heading: 2.2. Experimental methods
2.2.1. FT-IR, XRD, and SEM analysis of nano-HAP crystals
sections.text:
FT-IR: HAP was conducted with KBr discs in the region of 4000 cm−1 to 400 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, EQUINOX 55, Bruker, Germany).
XRD: Dried HAP crystals were recorded with Cu-Kα radiation at a scanning rate of 8° per min in the 2θ range from 5° to 55° with D/ max2400X X-ray powder diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan).
SEM: HAP suspension was prepared with absolute ethanol, prepared by ultrasonic dispersion, sprayed with gold, and then observed by SEM (Philips, Eindhoven, Netherlands). The average size of the HAP was determined by Nano Measurer 1.2.5 Software (Fudan University, China) from the SEM images. This size was a statistical result of the average data from 100 single particles.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Determination of zeta potential, conductivity, and surface structure of nano-HAP crystals
2.2.2.1. Detection of zeta potential and conductivity of each crystal in pure
sections.text:
water and culture solution. Four kinds of HAP crystals with different morphologies were dispersed in distilled water or DMEM/F-12 medium. The solution was prepared at a concentration of 0.10mg/mL. After ultrasonication for 5min, the zeta potential and conductivity of the crystal were measured by Zetasizer Nano ZS analyzer (Malvem, UK).
2.2.2.2. Determination of specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of crystal. Nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured at −196 °C by using a Tristar 3000 specific surface area and porosity analyzer (Micromeritics, USA). The specific surface area of the nanoparticles was determined via the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the data was processed by the BJH (Rod rett-Joyner-Halenda) method to obtain the pore size distribution curve, the pore volume value and the average pore diameter value of the crystal.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Cell culture
sections.text:
HK-2 cells were cultured in DMEM/F-12 supplemented with 10% FBS, 100 μg/mL penicillin and 100 μg/mL streptomycin in a 5% CO2 incubator at 37 °C. Trypsin digestion was performed for cell propagation. After the cells were synchronized, and divided into two groups: (A) control group in which only serum-free medium was added and (B) crystal treatment group in which HK-2 cells were exposed to 250 μg/mL H-Sphere, H-Needle, H-Rod and H-Plate crystals for 24 h.
Preparation of serum-free medium containing HAP: a certain amount of HAP crystals were plated, sterilized by ultraviolet light for 30min, and then dispersed in serum-free medium to prepare a suspension with a concentration of 500 μg/mL and treated with ultrasound for 5min.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Cell viability detection
sections.text:
The cytotoxicity of HAP crystals with various shapes was evaluated through a CCK-8 viability assay. The experimental model was divided into two groups: (A) control group: only serum-free medium was added; (B) crystal treatment group: HK-2 cells were exposed to 63, 125, 250 and 500 μg/mL H-Sphere, H-Needle, H-Rod and H-Plate crystals for 24 h. Then 10 μL CCK-8 was added to each well and incubated for 2 h at 37 °C. Absorbance was measured by using the microplate reader (Thermo Multiskan MK3, USA) at 450 nm.

sections.heading: 2.2.5. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) release assay
sections.text:
The experimental model was divided into four groups: (A) cell–free culture medium wells (control wells of background); (B) control wells without crystal treatment (sample control wells); (C) cells without
crystal treatment for the subsequent cleavage of the wells (sample maximum enzyme activity control wells); and (D) treated group with HSphere, H-Needle, H-Rod and H-Plate crystals at the 63, 125, 250 and 500 μg/mL for 24 h (drug–treated wells). After incubation, the absorbance was analyzed at 490 nm with a reference wavelength of 620 nm according to the LDH kit instruction.

sections.heading: 2.2.6. Cell morphology observation by hematoxylin-eosin (HE) staining
sections.text: The experimental model was grouped according to Section 2.2.3. After incubation for 24 h, the supernatant was removed. The cells were washed by PBS twice and fixed by 4% paraformaldehyde. Then it was stained with hematoxylin for 15min and eosin staining solution for 5min respectively. Observed under the microscope (OLYMPUS, CKX41, Japan), the nucleus was blue-violet, the cytoplasm was pink or red.

sections.heading: 2.2.7. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) detection
sections.text:
Qualitative observation: The experimental model was grouped according to Section 2.2.3. After incubation for 24 h, the samples were stained with DCFH-DA for 20min. The cells were then observed under a fluorescence microscope (Leica DMRA2, Germany).
Quantitative detection: After incubation for 24 h, the cells were stained with 200 μL of DCFH-DA, incubated at 37 °C for 20min in the dark, and washed twice with PBS to remove the unreacted DCFH-DA. The intensity of fluorescence was detected by microplate reader with an excitation wavelength of 488 nm and an emission wavelength of 525 nm.

sections.heading: 2.2.8. Detection of mitochondrial membrane potential (Δψm)
sections.text: The experimental model was grouped according to Section 2.2.3. The cells were collected and centrifuged at 1000 rpm/min for 5min. The supernatant was aspirated, washed with PBS, and centrifuged again to obtain a cell pellet. Then, 500 μL of JC-1 was added and incubated at 37 °C for 20min in the dark, then washed twice with PBS to remove the unreacted JC-1 and detected through flow cytometry (Beckman, Gallios, USA).

sections.heading: 2.2.9. Detection of lysosomal integrity
sections.text:
Qualitative observation: The experimental model was grouped according to Section 2.2.3 and stained with 5 μg/mL acridine orange dye (AO) solution prepared in DMEM/F-12 for 15min, then added the crystals and incubated for 24 h. Afterward, the supernatant was aspirated, and the cells were washed thrice with PBS. The distribution of AO in each cell was observed under a fluorescence microscope.
Quantitative detection: AO staining and cell processing was same as above. After incubation, the cells were washed with PBS prior to fluorescence measurements with excitation at 485 nm, and emission at 530 nm (green cytoplasmic AO) and 620 nm (red lysosomal AO). The following equations were used: normal lysosomal integrity= (total red fluorescence intensity)/(total green fluorescence intensity); lysosomal integrity= [(total red fluorescence intensity)/(total green fluorescence intensity)× (normal lysosomal integrity)].

sections.heading: 2.2.10. Cell cycle detection assay
sections.text: The experimental model was grouped according to Section 2.2.3. The cells were collected and centrifuged at1000 rpm/min for 5min. The supernatant was removed, and 1mL of 4 °C PBS buffer was added. The cells were suspended, centrifuged again, fixed in 700 μL ice-cold 70% ethanol and stored at −20 °C overnight. The cells were washed by PBS twice and resuspended in 200 μL of PI dye, then incubated for 15min at 37 °C in dark. At least 10,000 cells were collected and detected by flow cytometry.

sections.heading: 2.2.11. Localization of nano-HAP in HK-2 cells
sections.text: FITC-tagged HAP was prepared according to previous study [21]. Briefly, a mixture of 0.1 g HAP particles and 20mL AMPTES was mixed in 100mL anhydrous ethanol and stirred at 74 °C for 3 h. FITC (0.05 g) was then added and continued to react at 74 °C for another 6 h. The treated powders were filtered and washed with anhydrous ethanol and de-ionized water until no visible FITC on the HAP surfaces. Dried HAP crystals were obtained by exposing in air for 30min. After grouping the experimental model in accordance with Section 2.2.3, freshly prepared 250 μg/mL FITC-labeled HAP crystals were added to each group. After incubating for 24 h, the cell supernatant was removed, and the cells were washed twice with PBS. The cells were labeled with 70 nM LysoTracker Red for 2 h, and fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde for 30min. DAPI staining solution was then added to the cells and incubated for 5min. The cells were washed thrice with PBS for 5min, and the prepared samples were observed under a confocal microscope (LSM510 Meta Duo Scan, Zeiss, Germany).

sections.heading: 2.2.12. Quantitative analysis of internalized nano-HAP by flow cytometry
sections.text: After grouping the experimental model in accordance with Section 2.2.3, freshly prepared 250 μg/mL FITC-labeled HAP crystals were added to each group. After incubating for 24 h, the supernatant was removed; and the cells were washed twice with 5mM EDTA for 5min to remove adhered crystals [22]. Then, the cells were washed thrice with cold PBS to completely remove the external soluble HAP. The percentage of cells with internalized crystals was quantitatively determined through flow cytometry analysis. The cells with a positive FITC signal were directly counted and regarded as internalized crystals.

sections.heading: 2.2.13. Detection of apoptosis and necrosis
sections.text: The experimental model was grouped according to Section 2.2.3. After incubation for 24 h, suspended, and centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 5min. The supernatant was aspirated, washed with PBS, and centrifuged again to obtain a cell pellet. Then, 200 μL of binding buffer was added and mixed thoroughly. The cells were stained with 5 μL of Annexin V-FITC, incubated in the dark at room temperature for 10min, and centrifuged. The supernatant was removed. Afterward, 200 μL of binding buffer was added and mixed thoroughly. Then, 5 μL of propidium iodide (PI) was added to stain the cells. After the treatment was administered, the cells were detected through flow cytometry.

sections.heading: 2.2.14. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Experimental data were expressed by means ± standard deviation (x ± SD). The experimental results were analyzed statistically using SPSS 13.0 software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). Multiple group comparisons were performed using one-way ANOVA, followed by the Tukey post hoc test. If p < 0.05, there was significant difference; if p < 0.01, the difference was extremely significant; if p > 0.05, there was no significant difference.

sections.heading: 3. Results
3.1. Characterization of nano-HAP crystals with different morphologies using SEM, XRD, and FT-IR
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the SEM images of four different kinds of morphology nano-HAP crystals. The dimensions of H-Sphere, H-Needle, H-Rod, and H-Plate crystals were 72.5 nm×72.5 nm, 37.2 nm×162.7 nm, 42.3 nm×115.3 nm, and 145.5 nm×272.9 nm, respectively. The aspect ratios were approximately 1:1, 4:1, 3:1, and 2:1, respectively (Table 1).
Fig. S1A shows the XRD patterns of different morphologies of nanoHAP crystals. The diffraction peaks of interplanar spacing d=3.40, 2.79, 2.78, 2.63, 2.26, 1.93, and 1.82 nm corresponded to the (002), (211), (112), (202), (310), (222), and (213) planes of HAP (JCPDS No. 09-0432), respectively.
FT-IR spectrum (Fig. S1B) shows that the broad absorption peak near 3432 cm−1 and 1644 cm−1 belonged to the water adsorbed on the surface of HAP crystal, and the absorption peak near 3573 cm−1 was attributed to the O-H in HAP, but because the absorption peak of water was too strong, it appeared as a shoulder. The PO43− absorption band appeared at 1034, 960, 604, and 563 cm−1. CO32−-derived bands were observed around 1484 and 1416 cm−1, which probably occurred due to the adsorption of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere during sample preparation [23].
FT-IR and XRD spectroscopy results showed that all four HAPs were
pure phase crystals.

sections.heading: 3.2. Zeta potential, conductivity, and surface structure of nano-HAP crystals
3.2.1. Zeta potential
sections.text:
Table 2 shows the zeta potential values of HAP crystals dispersed in the medium and in water, all of which were negative (Table 2) and the absolute value of Zeta potential were ranked as follows: H-Sphere < HNeedle < H-Rod < H-Plate.
The absolute zeta potential value of each HAP solution in the medium was slightly smaller than their zeta potential in water, which was attributed to the large amount of inorganic ions (Ca2+ and Mg2+), amino acids, and vitamins in the DMEM/F-12 medium. PO43− on the surface of the HAP crystal be neutralized by Ca2+ and Mg2+ in the medium, thereby reducing the absolute zeta potential value of the HAP crystal.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Conductivity
sections.text:
Table 2 shows the conductivity of each HAP crystal in the culture medium and in water. HAP was a poorly soluble substance, and only a small amount of HAP was dissolved in water, so its conductivity value was low. Since DMEM/F-12 medium contained a large amount of
a The average crystal size was determined by Nano Measurer 1.2.5 Software from the SEM images. This size was a statistical result of the average data from 100 single particles.
b The size of H-Sphere is the diameter of the particles.
inorganic ions (Ca2+ and Mg2+), the conductivity of HAP crystals dispersed in the medium (14.0–14.3 mS/cm) was higher than that dispersed in water (0.185–0.655mS/cm).
3.2.3. Specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size Fig. S2 showed the adsorption, desorption, and pore size distribution curves of all HAP crystals. The adsorption–desorption curves of HSphere, H-Needle, and H-Plate were typical type III adsorption isotherms [24], indicating that the interaction between adsorbate N2 and these three HAP crystals was weak, and the pore volume distribution peaks significantly appeared for the three HAP crystals, indicating that these crystals were rough and had a relatively large specific surface area (Table 2).
It can be seen from Table 2 that the pore size of H-sphere and HNeedle (35.3 and 30.4 nm respectively) were close to its crystal width (72.5 and 37.3 nm respectively). The size distribution of HAP particles is a continuum rather than sets of uniform particles. In a medium of continuous distribution, the relationship between particle size and pore size is complicated, because small particles may be embedded in the voids between large particles, or large particles may float in the matrix of small particles [25]. In other words, there is no direct relationship between particle size and pore size. For example, Ibrahim et al. [26] synthesized seven kinds of rod-like HAP nanopowder from waste eggshells and phosphoric acid at room temperature. The particle size of the seven kinds of HAP was 11.0, 9.0, 9.0, 10.0, 19.0, 53.0, and 12.0 nm, and their pore diameter was 26.1, 17.4, 21.7, 25.0, 20.2, 16.4, and 26.7 nm, respectively.
The adsorption–desorption curve of H-Rod crystal was a typical Ιtype (microporous) adsorption isotherm [24], that is, the interaction between the adsorbed N2 and H-Rod crystals was relatively strong, the crystal surface did not have an obvious pore structure, and had a small specific surface area. The specific surface area SBET of each HAP crystal was ranked as follows: H-Plate (185.2) > H-Sphere (67.0) > HNeedle (52.5) > H-Rod (38.7 m2/g).

sections.heading: 3.3. Cell viability changes caused by Nano-HAP crystals
sections.text:
CCK-8 assay is a colorimetric assay for the determination of the number of viable cells by producing a water-soluble formazan dye upon reduction in the presence of an electron carrier using tetrazolium salt [27]. Fig. 2A shows the changes in cell viability of HK-2 cells treated with four kinds of HAP crystals for 24 h. All these crystals caused a decrease in cell viability and were concentration-dependent, that is, as the crystal concentration increased, the cell viability decreased.
At the same concentration, the toxicity of each crystal to HK-2 cells was ranked as follows: H-Sphere > H-Needle > H-Rod > H-Plate.

sections.heading: 3.4. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) release caused by nano-HAP crystals
sections.text:
The effect of HAP crystals on the cell membrane integrity of HK-2 cells was assessed by detecting the amount of LDH released into the culture fluid from the cells whose plasma membranes were disrupted [28]. As shown in Fig. 2B, the four HAPs caused a significant increase in the release of LDH compared with the control group, with a concentration effect, indicating that HAP crystals caused cell membrane damage. At the same concentration, H-Sphere and H-Needle caused a
higher LDH release than that of H-Rod and H-Plate crystals.

sections.heading: 3.5. Cell morphology changes caused by nano-HAP crystals
sections.text: Changes in cell morphology could directly reflect the degree of cell damage. The effect of each HAP crystal on the morphology of HK-2 cells was studied using HE staining (Fig. 3). Compared with normal control cells, all four HAPs caused changes in cell morphology. In the crystal treatment group, the connectivity between the cells was loose, and the cell gap was increased. Some cells showed swelling, and some cells showed nuclear condensation. At the same concentration, the damage of H-Sphere and H-Needle crystals on cell morphology was greater than those of H-Rod and H-Plate crystals.

sections.heading: 3.6. Increase in ROS generation induced by nano-HAP crystals
sections.text:
Intracellular ROS levels reflect the oxidative toxicity of crystals. Nano-HAP crystal-induced changes in ROS produced in HK-2 cells were detected using a DCFH-DA fluorescent probe (Fig. 4). The cells in the normal group had dark fluorescence, indicating low levels of intracellular ROS. The green fluorescence of each HAP-treated group was significantly enhanced, indicating that HAP crystals caused an increase in intracellular ROS levels.
Quantitative results of fluorescence intensity (Fig. 4B) indicated that the amount of ROS generated by the four groups of HAP-treated cells was ranked as follows: H-Sphere (55,300 a.u.) > H-Needle (52,760 a.u.) > H-Rod (50,560 a.u.) > H-Plate (42,460 a.u.) > Control (33,140 a.u.).

sections.heading: 3.7. Decrease in mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm) induced by nano-HAP crystals
sections.text:
Fluorescent probe JC-1 is a cationic lipophilic dye that can penetrate the cell membrane freely. When Δψm is high, JC-1 accumulates in the mitochondrial matrix to form polymers (J-aggregates), producing red fluorescence (high ΔΨm). Conversely, when Δψm is low, JC-1 cannot accumulate in the mitochondrial matrix. JC-1 is a monomer, which produces green fluorescence. The living cells have a high ΔΨm and a strong red fluorescence. ΔΨm of apoptotic and necrotic cells are decreased.
As shown in Fig. 5, the ratio of the cells with low ΔΨm (green fluorescence) to the normal cells was 0.55%, whereas all the four crystal treatment groups induced different degrees of mitochondrial depolarization, resulting in an increase in the ratio of low ΔΨm cells, and was ranked as follows: H-Sphere (24.40%) > H-Needle (21.43%) > H-Rod (11.86%) > H-Plate (9.88%). The increase in intracellular ROS levels caused by HAP crystals might have caused the decrease in ΔΨm.

sections.heading: 3.8. Lysosomal integrity changes induced by nano-HAP crystals
sections.text:
Acridine orange (AO) can enter the lysosomes through the cell
membrane and combine with internal acid hydrolase to emit an orangered fluorescence. AO in the cytoplasm shows green fluorescence [29]. The lysosomes in the normal and early apoptotic cells retained their intact structure and emitted strong red fluorescence, whereas the lysosomes in the necrotic cells ruptured and emitted weak red fluorescence [30]. Thus, the degree of lysosome damage could be determined by measuring the fluorescence intensity ratio of red and green fluorescence.
As shown in Fig. 6, the red and green fluorescence in the normal group showed a strong orange-red color, and the lysosome structure remained almost intact. In the four HAP treatment groups, the red fluorescence was significantly attenuated, and the superimposed yellowish red color weakened (Fig. 6A). Quantitative detection results (Fig. 6B) showed that the lysosome integrity in the H-Sphere, H-Needle, H-Rod, and H-Plate treatment groups was 66.58%, 72.20%, 78.70%, and 84.63%, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.9. Cell cycle distribution changes induced by nano-HAP crystals
sections.text:
Unscheduled DNA replication and failed cell cycle progression leading to cell death [31]. Propidium iodide (PI) is a fluorescent dye of double-stranded DNA whose fluorescence intensity is directly proportional to the content of double-stranded DNA.
As shown in Fig. 7, the four HAP crystals led to an increase in the proportion of cells in the G0/G1 phase (pre-DNA synthesis). The proportion of cells during G0/G1 was 85%, 76.1%, 72.3%, and 65.2%, respectively, in the H-Sphere, H-Needle, H-Rod, and H-Plate treated groups, which were all greater than the 57.6% of the control group. The proportion of S phase (DNA synthesis period) cells decreased, which was 3.4%, 8.8%, 15.5%, and 22.5%, respectively, all of which are< 30.5% of the control group. All HAP crystals blocked cell proliferation, and their retention ability in the G0/G1 phase was consistent with the cytotoxicity order of the crystals.

sections.heading: 3.10. Localization of nano-HAP in HK-2 cells
sections.text:
Nano-HAP crystals were labeled with FITC (green), and the nuclei (blue) and lysosomes (red) were labeled with DAPI and Lyso-Tracker
Red. The position of the nano-HAP crystals in the cells was localized using confocal microscopy.
The green fluorescence of HAP crystals and red fluorescence of intracellular lysosomes showed a yellow-green fluorescence (Fig. 8), indicating that HAP crystals accumulated in the lysosomes after they were internalized into the cells. This internalization process was related to the morphology of the crystals. As HAP crystal morphology was changed from the H-Sphere, H-Needle, H-Rod, and to H-Plate, the yellow-green fluorescence was reduced and the green fluorescence was increased, indicating a decrease in the number of crystals distributed in the lysosome.

sections.heading: 3.11. Internalization of nano-HAP crystals by HK-2 cells
sections.text: Fig. 9 shows that cells with FITC signals could be considered as cells with endocytic crystal. The four kinds of HAP crystals could be internalized by HK-2 cells, and the percentage of cells containing internalized HAP crystals was ranked as follows: HAP-Sphere (32.3%) > HAP-Needle (24.4%) > HAP-Rod (19.1%) > HAP-Plate (14.8%) > Control group (0.58%) (Fig. 9B). This ratio was negatively correlated with cell viability (R2= 0.851, Fig. 9C), that is, the more crystals internalized, the lower the cell viability.

sections.heading: 3.12. Effect of nano-HAP on apoptosis and necrosis of HK-2 cells
sections.text:
The number of apoptosis and necrosis was quantified by using flow cytometry with Annexin V-FITC/PI double staining. Fig. 10 shows the changes in apoptosis and necrosis of HK-2 cells induced by four HAP crystals. The apoptotic rate (Q4) and total necrosis rate (Q1+Q2) percentage in the normal group of 1.5% and 2.1%, respectively, was low. Although the four HAPs caused significant cell necrosis, apoptosis was not significant (Fig. 10B), indicating that HAP crystals mainly caused cell necrosis. The total necrosis rate of HK-2 cells induced by the four crystals was ranked as follows: H-Sphere (34.5%) > H-Needle (28.9%) > H-Rod (23.9%) > H-Plate (12.5%).
Zhao et al. [32] had shown that needle and plate nano-HAP mainly led to necrosis in the human normal lung epithelial cells, which may be related to the high level of induced IL-6. Liu et al. [33] showed that calcium phosphate nanoparticles could destroy the integrity of lysosomes through osmotic pressure imbalance, and excessive lysosomal rupture eventually led to cell necrosis.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
4.1. Toxicity mechanism of nano-HAP crystals on HK-2 cells
sections.text:
Results of cell viability and LDH release (Fig. 2) showed that the cytotoxicity of nano-HAP to HK-2 was ranked as follows: H-Sphere > H-Needle > H-Rod > H-Plate. The cell morphology observation showed the same results (Fig. 3).
Excessive production of ROS is an important mechanism of nanocrystal toxicity [34]. Excessive production of ROS induced oxidative
stress, leading to normal dysfunction of renal epithelial cells and cell death [34], thereby promoting the deposition of crystals in the kidney [35] and increasing the risk of kidney stone formation.
ROS was also a direct cause of the decrease in ΔΨm. ROS mostly occurs in the mitochondria. High levels of ROS can induce changes in the mitochondrial membrane permeability, mitochondrial membrane potential depolarization, respiratory chain disruption, and mitochondrial function disruption, leading to apoptosis or necrosis [36]. All HAP crystals caused a significant decrease in ΔΨm (Fig. 5), which was consistent with the increasing order of ROS (Fig. 4).
The rupture of lysosomes is an important feature of cell necrosis [37,38]. Calcium phosphate nanoparticles can destroy lysosomes by causing osmotic pressure imbalance, leading to cell self-repair and imbalance of homeostatic mechanisms, leading to cell necrosis [38,39]. All HAP crystals destroyed the integrity of intracellular lysosomes as Fig. 6.
Oxidative stress could also cause DNA damage leading to cell cycle arrest [40]. All four HAPs led to cell cycle arrest in the G0/G1 phase (Fig. 7), and the blocking effect of H-Sphere and H-Needle was more pronounced than that of H-Rod and H-Plate. The G1 phase is a critical stage in determining the state of cell proliferation, and its detection point, called the R point, regulates the cell proliferation cycle. R point prevents the damaged cells from entering the S phase, allowing the cells to exit the cell cycle directly from the G1 phase and enter the death program [41]. Treatment of Bel-7402 cancer cells with nano-HAP had similar results [42,43].
The internalization and accumulation of nanoparticles in cells were also important factors in HAP-induced cytotoxicity [44]. HAP was primarily localized in lysosomes after entering the cells (Fig. 8). The percentage of cells with internalized crystal was ranked as Fig. 9. A negative correlation exists between the amount of internalization of the
crystal and the viability of the cells [45]. Yin et al. [46] showed that nano-HAP entered Bel-7402 cells by internalization, causing changes in cell ultrastructure and inhibiting cell proliferation. In addition, internalization caused a significant loss of adhesion of the suspended Bel7402 cells, which eventually died.
Fig. 11 shows a schematic diagram of the mechanism of nano-HAP cytotoxicity against HK-2. HAP crystals can cause cell membrane damage and cell morphology changes, resulting in a large number of intracellular ROS production, ΔΨm decrease, and accumulation of nanoHAP crystals in the lysosomes, under the action of acid hydrolase release Ca2+ and PO43−, which in turn led to lysosomal rupture. Cell cycle was arrested in the G0/G1 phase, causing loss of normal cell function and inducing cell necrotic death. Damaged cells exacerbated the adhesion and aggregation of CaOx crystals, thereby increasing the risk of kidney stones.

sections.heading: 4.2. Physical properties of HAP affect cytotoxicity
4.2.1. Effect of surface charge of crystals
sections.text:
Cellular uptake of nano-HAP has two stages, including the attachment of HAP to the cell membrane followed by internalization of HAP
[47]. The attachment of HAP to the cell membrane as a first step in internalization seemed most affected by the surface charge of HAP [48]. The mechanisms of internalization involved several possible mechanisms, including pinocytosis, non-specific endocytosis, and receptormediated endocytosis [48]. Since most cell membrane surfaces had large areas of negatively charged regions, crystals with a more negative zeta potential on the surface increased crystal–cell repulsion [49]. However, Wilhelm et al. [47] showed that cell membranes with large areas of negatively charged regions could also exhibit a highly efficient internalization of negatively charged nanoparticles because this was
believed to occur through nonspecific binding and clustering of the particles on cationic sites on the plasma membrane (that are relatively scarcer than negatively charged domains) and their subsequent internalization. In addition, the negatively charged particles were bound to the cationic site in the form of clusters due to the repulsive interaction of the negatively charged domains on the cell surface.
Table 2 shows the zeta potential values of four kinds of nano-HAP. The more negative the zeta potential of the crystal, the more repulsive interaction between the crystal-cells, and the lower internalization of the crystals. Therefore, H-Rod and H-Plate with a more negative zeta
potential had lower cytotoxicity than H-Sphere and H-Needle. He et al. [45] showed that the internalization of negatively charged nanoparticles (RhB-CMCNP rhodamine B labeled carboxymethyl chitosan grafted NPs) by human normal hepatocytes and human hepatoma cells decreased with the increase of surface charge.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Energy required for internalization: important factor to affect the cytotoxicity of H-sphere and H-plate crystals
sections.text:
Typically, nanocrystals enter the cell through membrane encapsulation and simultaneous rotation [50], which are extremely energy mediated processes [50,51]. The difference in the energy required to overcome the bending resistance of the film during wrapping influenced the difference in the internalization of crystals of different
morphologies that enter the cell wrapping stage [52]. Spherical nanoparticles were more conducive to internalization than non-spherical nanoparticles [50,51].
A minimum bending energy of the elastic membrane must be overcome during H-Sphere internalization, which further damaged cells and their subcellular organelles. H-Needle, H-Rod, and especially HPlate had irregular structures. Their internalization was difficult because it entailed a stronger membrane deformation and complex rotation, which required more energy compared with those of H-sphere. HSphere exhibited the highest cytotoxicity, whereas H-Plate exhibited the lowest cytotoxicity because cells had a positive correlation between internalization crystal and crystal cytotoxicity [45,53].
Li et al. [54] compared the cell internalization efficiency of
spherical, cubic, rod, and plate nanoparticles with the same surface area by theoretically calculating the free energy barrier. Results showed that the cell internalization efficiency of spherical particles (100%) was higher than that of other non-spherical nanoparticles (87%–65%). Chithrani et al. [51] showed that the cell internalization of spherical nanoparticles was 2–4 times higher than that of rods.
4.2.3. Effect of specific surface area of crystals Crystals with large specific surface area usually have a large contact area with the cell surface, so they are more likely to cause damage to the cell [18,55].
In this study, the specific surface areas of H-Sphere, H-Needle, and H-Rod (Table 2) were consistent with their cytotoxicity, that is, HSphere>H-Needle>H-Rod.

sections.heading: 4.2.4. Effect of aspect ratio of crystals
sections.text: The cytotoxicity of crystals is affected by their length to width ratio. In the case of similar width, crystals with higher aspect ratios can be internalized rapidly and in large quantities [56], showing high cytotoxicity. The length to width ratios of H-Needle (4:1), H-Rod (3:1), and H-Plate (2:1) decreased, resulting in the decrease of their toxicity. Santos et al. [57] showed that needle-like HAP nanoparticles with high aspect ratio exhibited higher toxicity than rods with smaller aspect ratio.

sections.heading: 4.2.5. Effect of the size of crystal
sections.text:
The smaller the particle, the greater the tendency to enter the subcellular organelles, and the greater the cytotoxicity [45,58,59]. HPlate showed the lowest toxicity because its particle size (272.9 nm) was larger than that of H-Sphere (72.5 nm), H-Needle (162.7 nm), and H-Rod (115.3 nm). At the same concentration, small particles have
more active sites than large particles. These active sites can capture oxygen molecules and produce superoxide radical through Fenton reaction or dismutation [59]. Excessively produced ROS can induce mitochondrial membrane permeability, mitochondrial ultrastructure damage and respiratory chain rupture, leading to cell death [60]. Therefore, small-sized HAP (spherical, needle-shaped and rod-shaped) has more serious damage to cells than large-sized H-Plate.
Yu et al. [61] studied the cytotoxicity of amorphous silica (SiO2) particles with particle sizes of 30, 48, 118, and 535 nm on mouse keratinocytes and found that the smaller the SiO2 particles, the greater the cytotoxicity. Yuan et al. [21] showed that the cytotoxicity of HAP with particle sizes of 26 nm and 45 nm to HepG2 cells was greater than that of HAP with particle sizes of 78 nm and 175 nm. Xu et al. [62] studied the effects of human colon adenocarcinoma cells (Caco-2) and human colon cancer cells (HT-29) on the uptake of Coumarin-6 (C6) loaded
poly (lactide-co-glycolide) nanoparticles with particle sizes of 50, 100, 150, 200, and 300 nm. C6 internalization was size dependent, and had an optimal particle size of 100 nm. A critical size (98 nm) was obtained by calculating the relationship between the diameter of nanoparticles and the internalization rate. When the radius was<98 nm, the internalization rate increased with the increase of the particle size. When the radius was> 98 nm, the internalization rate decreased with increase in size.
The toxicity of different morphological HAP crystals to cells was the result of a combination of various properties of the crystals (Table 3).
a) Although H-Sphere had the lowest aspect ratio, it had the most favorable spherical morphology for internalization, the lowest absolute zeta potential value, and the smallest particle size, which made it the most cytotoxic among the four crystals.
b) H-Needle and H-Rod had moderate zeta potential values and specific surface areas, so their toxicity was higher than H-Plate and lower than H-Sphere. Compared with H-Rod, H-Needle had a lower absolute zeta potential value, higher aspect ratio, and larger specific surface area, so H-Needle had a higher cytotoxicity than H-Rod. c) H-Plate showed the lowest toxicity with the largest specific surface area. H-Plate had an irregular structure and its specific surface area did not reflect the true contact area between the crystal and the cell surface, which was not conducive to cell internalization. H-Plate's irregular morphology, negative surface zeta potential, and maximum size explain why it had the lowest cytotoxicity.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text: The cytotoxicity of HAP crystals was closely related to their physical properties. HAP crystals with low absolute zeta potential value, a morphology conducive to internalization, large specific surface area, large aspect ratio, and small particle size are more toxic to HK-2 cells. Understanding the toxicity of HAP crystal with different physical properties on renal epithelial cells will not only help in understanding the formation mechanism of Randall's plaque, but will also help in preventing the formation of kidney stones.

referenceMentions.context: Research has shown that HAP at 20–40 nm plays an important role in the formation of biominerals [1].
Randall plaque formed by HAP on the surface of renal epithelial cells in the urinary system is important causes of stone formation [2].
In Randall plaques, there are HAP crystals with different sizes from nanometer to micrometer, and also HAP crystals with different morphologies [2].
Calcium oxalate (CaOx) is a common type of kidney stone whose formation mechanism is not yet fully elucidated [3].
HAP and uric acid are the main crystal nests that induce the formation of CaOx stones, but relatively few studies in this area were conducted [4,5].
HAP and uric acid are the main crystal nests that induce the formation of CaOx stones, but relatively few studies in this area were conducted [4,5].
Overgrowth of CaOx upon renal papillary Randall's plaque has been proposed as a potential mechanism of stone formation [6].

The percent of plaque coverage directly correlates with the number of stones formed and supports the hypothesis that the pathogenesis of CaOx stones begins with Randall's plaques [7], which are in contact with supersaturated urine in adjacent nephrons.

Consequently, CaOx was induced to precipitate on its surface and cause heterogeneous nucleation that further promotes the growth and aggregation of CaOx crystals in renal epithelial cells [8], thus increasing the risk of kidney stone formation.
HAP is the main component of Randall's plaque [2,9,10].

metadata.abstractText: Hydroxyapatite (HAP) is not only a common component of most idiopathic CaOx stones, but also the core of Randall's plaque. HAP is a nest that can induce the formation of Randall's plaques and even kidney stones. We studied the toxic effects and mechanisms of four different types of nano-HAP crystals (H-Sphere, 72.5 nm×72.5 nm; H-Needle, 37.2 nm×162.7 nm; H-Rod, 42.3 nm×115.3 nm; and H-Plate, 145.5 nm×272.9 nm) on human renal proximal tubular epithelial cells (HK-2). HAP crystals could cause oxidative stress that triggered a series of cell dysfunction problems, resulting in decreased cell viability, loss of cell membrane integrity, cell swelling, and cell necrosis. The toxic effect of HAP was mainly attributed to its entry into cell by endocytosis and its accumulation in the lysosomes, causing the level of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) to rise, the mitochondrial membrane potential (Δψm) to decrease, the lysosomal integrity to be destroyed, and the cell cycle blocked during the G0/G1 phase. The cytotoxicity of the four kinds of HAP crystals was ranked as follows: H-Sphere > H-Needle > H-Rod > H-Plate. The cytotoxicity of each crystal was positively correlated with low absolute zeta potential, conduciveness to internalized morphology, large specific surface area and aspect ratio, and small particle size. These results indicated that nano-HAP could damage HK-2 cells, and the physical properties of HAP crystals play a vital effect in their cytotoxicity.
